Apollo computer is well documented. The processor was executing each instruction in 12 micro-second. It executed 83 thousands instruction per second.

Since, by today standard, a processor execute at least one instruction per clock cycle, the stated clock frequency should say 83 KHz. If is credible that the Apollo computer was using 12 clock cycle per instruction, so the 1 MHz frequency is correct.

While this is a pretty fair shake at things, I must nitpick some.

-Skipped Bertie the Brain which was likely the first gaming computer.

-Skipped Christopher Strachey's draughts game which would have served as a more interesting way to talk about AI. Also (possibly) the first "video" game in the traditional sense because it may have been displayed on the Mark 1's cathode screen.

-There's no indication that NIMROD inspired Douglas. Also I have no idea where you got that picture from.

-The TMRC didn't sneak into labs, they were granted access by Jack Dennis.

-No mention of the other people involved with Spacewar! ? J Martin Graetz is most certainly a co-author even if you discount everyone else.

-Spacewar! was not included on the PDP operating system. They made brochures and distributed it, but no definitive evidence exists of them actually shipping it with the computers (IBM distributed things like Jack Burgeson's The Baseball Demonstration through catalogs).

I feel like there's a fairly sizeable chunk of game history missing between the last episode and this one. Board games? Number games? Logic puzzles? Toys? Word games? Mechanical games? Pinball? Jigsaws? Card games? Tabletop games? All these things happened well before and continued during the advent of computing, there's almost an entire segment on each of those sections alone before video games come on the scene, and all of them are influential in one way or another on how videogames came to be designed and developed.
Basically what I'm saying is: expand the series plz ;)

Oh the Dreamcast. I remember when that was out. Funny it was one of the game systems my late mom almost bought. There was something else too, but I can't remember what it was. But it was no longer available at the time. In the end my first game system was a Sega Genesis that my dad sent me used with three games, Eternal Champions which I loved, the 7Up spots game, and some kind of Olympics game. I even played the Eternal Champions on two player by myself with the second player being my feet, and my feet actually did beat me several times.
Later on I got my Gameboy Color and for a time that was it, until I talked her in to getting me my PS2 that still works and I mostly use it as a DVD player, and later on the Gamecube, which I no longer have. But I have kept up with the 3DSXL and my god it was the first game system I've had that was still early in it's release and still is popular.

I remember the early days of the term hacker. I was surprised to see his implication of the origin. Back in the days of the typewriter, typists where tough to type without looking a the keyboard. This is so they can be reading something and transcribing it at the same time. This method used all of your fingers. Some typewriter users didn't transcribe
though. Fir instance writers and paternalists. Many of them developed a habit of using one finger on each hand and "hacking" at the keyboards. May typesets saw this as improper typing technique and developed the derogatory term "hack types".
In comes computer keyboards and enthusiast that where mostly engineering type students with no formal taring in typing. As a result, most computer enthusiast' used the hack typing style. This led to computer enthusiast adopting the name of "hacker". Later some of these hackers started breaking into computer. This started making into popular print mediums that used the more generic term of hackers with referring to the people who did this. Since the more general definition of the term wasn't usually presented to the public, the term eventually took on the meaning of a malicious person that attacker computer systems.
I am not saying that he is wrong. It may be multiple origins of the term. I lived though this though.

It is a cliche. We don't talk about computing in cars the same way we discuss computers in the space program. The truth is that sending a rocket to the moon is.....well only rocket science. The math involved in plotting a course to an object in our own orbit is relatively simple. And the computers weren't storing videos, music and cat pictures. They were devoid of graphical interfaces and sound cards.

You might have bothered to explain computer games as they existed before the advent of CRT monitor screens, which were primarily used to monitor computer activity prior to requesting a printout. Most people played text based games on printers that had no graphics or monitors whatsoever, but were a lot of fun. So fun were they that the computer departments of most schools, colleges, and universities would set limits on the amount of paper that students could use, which were intended for their class studies.

Students had to become resourceful if they intended to continue their new love of computer gaming, and they began to dumpster-drive likely place where people threw out lots of unused paper. One such popular place was the dumpsters of telephone interchanges. They had computers with large fancy, dot-matrix printers, which often only printed out reports on the left side of 17" long graph paper. By taking these used printouts students could just use the back or right side of the paper for their own computer printouts.

Some more curious student began reading what the telephone company was printing out on these pages, and, because so many of these students were themselves learning to become computer science engineers, learned how the telephone company used and operated the telephone interchanges. This lead to some students hacking into and phone phreaking the entire telephone network.

Since the telephone company thought that no one outside the company would ever use the system they setup to their own advantage, there were no security or passwords whatsoever. You couldn't call what some students did "breaking into they system" because the system didn't have any doors to keep people out. Most school departments of computer science set up student accounts with password. No such beast existed in the telephone company. There was no login. You were always in. And they helpfully supplied the telephone book of operations and codes for anyone in the system to printout and learn how to use and abuse it.
Please stop trying so hard to be fun, it's really annoying.

My PC has 16GB of RAM. But it has 5 TB of Secondary Storage. NASAs Computer had 4KB of Main Memory. The new Iphone has 2GB of Main Memory. 16GB is the size of its secondary storage.

Spacewar! was done on a vector graphic CRT similar to early RADAR screens. The ships were drawn by diverting an electron beam's X and Y coordinates. It was a major form of graphic display until raster computer graphics were developed. Raster graphics grew from analog television technology which redraws every point on the screen from top to bottom.

Spacewar was a 2-player only game, right? So I can totally understand how that game would have been so awesome back in the day when this all began. I mean it was all new, people didn't yet know how any of this worked and had to get used to the feeling of actually controlling something on a screen that wasn't mechanical. And with the difficult-ish controls, the gravity feature, the head-to-head competition as well as the novelty of a commercially available videogame, I can totally see people being mesmerized by this for hours.

Spacewar, once it was turned into an actual arcade machine (Renammed "Space Wars")  was an amazingly fun two player game!  I remember having so many intense shoot outs in this gamewith my friends in the late 70's in the bowling alley where the machine was. It was a great game.  There's also an Atari 2600 cartridge of this game, but it pales in comparison to the actual game.

The Computer History Museum in Mountain View CA occasionally has demos of the PDP-1 with Steve Russel and another MIT grad where they actually fire up the machine and let you play Spacewar! I can't remember the other guy's name but his hack was to wire up a guitar amp to one of the front panel lights and actually play computer generated music through it. I was awe struck!
